commit_message:
Add retries to apt cache update

Updating the apt cache sometimes fails due to it being
an operation that uses mirrors on the internet. The
task should be retried to reduce the chance of a
transient failure causing the playbook to fail.

Change-Id: Ia53420dc3c19928afdc0740328b77aacee697f1d
Partial-Bug: #1750656

commit_message:
Use constraints for all pip package installations

Currently we're installing pip packages into the venv
unconstrained, resulting in the possibility of an
inconsistent build. This has luckily been covered by
the repo build process only making a single, correct
version of a python package available. However, for
role tests it is now failing because it's pulling in
a new version of libvirt-python which doesn't work
with the libvirt version used in newton.

Change-Id: I1607685ac6b30b698dacf5f05c4f5639ae53df44

commit_message:
Add Rocky Priorities

Change-Id: I9cd7bda400e5aeeb5644fc9cf2537c71cf59f26e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/74/550174/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. _rocky-priorities: ======================== Rocky Project Priorities ======================== This is a list of development priorities the Ironic team is prioritizing for Rocky development, in order of priority. Note that this is not our complete backlog for the cycle, we still hope to review and land non-priority items. The primary contact(s) listed is/are responsible for tracking the status of that work and herding cats to help get that work done. They are not the only contributor(s) to this work, and not necessary doing most of the coding! They are expected to be available on IRC and the ML for questions, and report status on the whiteboard_ for the weekly IRC sync-up. The number of primary contacts is limited to 2-3 maximum to simplify communication. We expect at least one of them to have core privileges to simplify getting changes in. .. _whiteboard: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/IronicWhiteBoard Essential Priorities ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ +---------------------------------------+-------------------------------------+ | Priority | Primary Contacts | +=======================================+=====================================+ | `Deploy Steps`_ | TBD | +---------------------------------------+-------------------------------------+ | `BIOS config framework`_ | ?yolanda?, ?rpioso? | +---------------------------------------+-------------------------------------+ | `Conductor Location Awareness`_ | jroll | +---------------------------------------+-------------------------------------+ | `Reference architecture guide`_ | dtantsur, TheJulia, ?sambetts? | +---------------------------------------+-------------------------------------+ | `Graphical console`_ | pas-ha, TBD | +---------------------------------------+-------------------------------------+ | `Neutron Event Processing`_ | TBD | +---------------------------------------+-------------------------------------+ High Priorities ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ +---------------------------------------+-------------------------------------+ | Priority | Primary Contacts | +=======================================+=====================================+ | `Refactoring virt driver`_ | TheJulia | +---------------------------------------+-------------------------------------+ | `Storyboard migration`_ | TheJulia | +---------------------------------------+-------------------------------------+ | `Management interface refactoring`_ | ?etingof? | +---------------------------------------+-------------------------------------+ | `Getting clean steps`_ | ?rloo?, ?TheJulia? | +---------------------------------------+-------------------------------------+ | `Project vision`_ | jroll, TheJulia | +---------------------------------------+-------------------------------------+ | `HUP Support`_ | rloo | +---------------------------------------+-------------------------------------+ Other Items ~~~~~~~~~~~ +---------------------------------------+-------------------------------------+ | Priority | Primary Contacts | +=======================================+=====================================+ | `Classic driver removal`_ | dtantsur | +---------------------------------------+-------------------------------------+ | `Redfish OOB inspection`_ | ?etingof? | +---------------------------------------+-------------------------------------+ | `Zuul v3 playbook refactoring`_ | sambetts, pas-ha | +---------------------------------------+-------------------------------------+ Details ~~~~~~~ Deploy Steps ------------ We created cleaning with the the ability to compose an ordered list of actions to be taken. However we left deployment as a static set of actions. In order to allow templates to apply using chosen traits, we want to have the same functionality. This will start with the goal of splitting apart the action of writing the image during the deployment from the act of writing the configuration drive into two distinct steps. From there, we will further iterate. This may ultimately may facilitate de-duplication of deployment logic which was an uncompleted goal from the Queens development cycle. BIOS config framework --------------------- Some drivers support setting BIOS (UEFI, etc) configuration out-of-band. We would like to introduce a framework (HTTP and driver API) for drivers to expose this feature to users. Conductor location awareness ---------------------------- Often operators have made changes to driver names to facilitate mapping of conductors to individual nodes, such that conductors are local to nodes, and a conductor in Las Angeles is not trying to control machines in Europe. This allows ironic to remain a single pane of glass, and provides increased flexibility in deployments of ironic. For now, we will focus our limit on hard affinity with an upgrade path. Reference architecture guide ---------------------------- To help new deployers make the right choices, we need a document describing a reference architecture for an ironic deployment, especially around multi-tenant networking and co-existing with VMs. Graphical console ----------------- We need a way to expose graphical (e.g. VNC) consoles to users from drivers that support it. Specifications and patches are in various states, and need to be picked up again. We are hoping to have the intial framework to support graphical console usage in this cycle. Neutron event processing ------------------------ Currently ironic has no way to determine when certain asynchronous events actually finish in neutron, and with what result. Nova, on the contrary, uses a special neutron driver, which filters out notifications and posts some of them to a special nova API endpoint. We should do the same. Refactoring virt driver ----------------------- Cycle after cycle we encounter issues with the upgrade sequence and the API version pin that we increment in the Nova virt driver that supports ironic. It is time to put this to an end and better properly support versioned interactions with our API. Upon discussing with the Nova community, we reached consensus that it is time to transition our API calls to direct REST calls as opposed to calls through the python-ironicclient library. Storyboard migration -------------------- Ironic has planned work in many different ways over the years, and we have learned that there are positives to each approach. As our team has also become smaller, we must also enable better focus by integrating distinct tools, systems, and processes together. With Storyboard, we will gain the advantage of planning and tracking work in a single system. Management interface refactoring -------------------------------- As time has gone on, we have found the need to have a single place to control the boot interface for nodes. This effort is refactoring the interface so we move distinct boot mode related actions into a single method. Getting clean steps ------------------- One of the biggest frustrations that people have with our cleaning model is the lack of visibility into what they can do. We have ideas on this and we need to begin providing the mechanisms to raise that visibility. Project vision -------------- We all have have different ideas of where we would like to see ironic in two, five, and ten years. Discussing this as a group helped us scope and frame our discussions so we were on the same page. We should write down our collective vision of the future, and see where it takes us. HUP support ----------- Supporting HUP is an OpenStack project wide goal, and it should be easy for us. Lets do it! Classic driver removal ---------------------- We have deprecated the classic drivers, and soon is approaching the time to remove these drivers now that we have provided a means to migrate users to hardware types. Redfish OOB inspection ---------------------- Redfish is one of our in-tree "reference" interface types, however we have no support for out-of-band inspection. In terms of providing feature parity, we should move forward with this, as more vendors are moving to Redfish. Zuul v3 playbook refactoring ---------------------------- One of the powerful features with Zuul v3 is that we execute ansible playbooks as opposed to traditional shell scripting. The migration left quite a bit of legacy shell scripts in the testing process. Efforts are underway to remove the bulk of this launch scripting from our normal devstack jobs. We should expect our grenade jobs to remain untouched.

commit_message:
Ensure leader settings on charm upgrade

Currently bootstrapping is gated by is_leader_bootstrapped which
checks a handful of leader settings. When upgrading from older
versions of the charm, these settings are missing leading to an
attempt to bootstrap an already bootstrapped cluster.

This change makes sure the leader settings is_leader_bootstrapped is
checking for are all set by the leader on upgrade-charm.

Closes-Bug: #1755507

Change-Id: I172f10221b9447ca3e0c5403feaa49acccfa9e42
(cherry picked from commit 5bce1985e1fdc590a96050be7f35ea9a6d5358e3)

commit_message:
Update modules to contain core.py for Sphinx

Apparently Sphinx will now ignore modules that *only* contain an
__init__.py file, regardless of sub-directories being present. This
commit simply adds a core.py file to the directory with a FIXME that
explains its existance. This is just to get the documentation jobs
passing until we can refactor those modules to a point where Sphinx
doesn't ignore them.

Change-Id: I9286574334464b2ff56ae82ad5bf85c8d995a852
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/25/552925/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # FIXME: Apparently Sphinx 1.6.7 ignores directory that only contain # __init__.py files, regardless of subdirectories being present. This file is # here solely to get documentation to build, at least until we refactor various # parts of this module so that we don't hit this issue with Sphinx.

commit_message:
Add version and git sha to debug modal

We add the 'version' and 'gitSha' keys to the AppConfig record, and we
implement the appropriate selectors.  The old webpack version loader is
repurposed into a DefinePlugin which we use to define the VERSION and
GITSHA variables.  Those are read during store hydration, and their
values are stored in the app state.

Change-Id: I9fbef9c62c150aa89bc44bfb8065976a73efde25
Closes-Bug: #1731972

commit_message:
Move neutron to requirements.txt

Neutron was added to global-requirements [1] which breaks the tox
install of neutron. Neutron is now listed in requirements.txt and has
been removed as a dependency in tox.ini. One side effect is that we
based the policy.json path on the location of the neutron git directory
which is no longer the case. The test code has been updated to reflect
the new location of the policy file.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/550475/

Change-Id: Ibc42b8a835d1a5e6ce09640f5bdf833c2171a9a9

Not adding this template lead to a change in the control port ip

'}]
commit_message:
[FFU] For deployed server in CI, make sure to get the compta layer.

Not adding this template lead to a change in the control port ip
address, because name has changed and resource has become a nested
one.

The deployed_server variable is set in the featureset of the upstream
jobs.

Change-Id: I22ef4bd08e1b1fb7545b4a2eca8b55ca6081c3bd

commit_message:
Wire up --skip-tags to the overcloud upgrade cli

This is already wired into the ansible-action [1] so this review just
adds skip_tags to the update_nodes workflow which calls that
action. There is a related review in the tripleoclient
Ie7fb8d9a388c6d53a31800406b03ddb8ed426401 that exposes
--skip-tags to the operator and passes it here, and that review
will depend on this one.

[1]  https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-common/blob/4739027b9eaf3dc895b29b67dbca0ffc79b36d4b/tripleo_common/actions/ansible.py#L259
Change-Id: I8544de64d3307e3dc925c1cecf2d9156e31d25a8

commit_message:
Check for conflict before bumping subnet's revision number

All updates method should check if the transaction was actually
committed prior to bumping the revision number on an update. The subnet
guard code was missing.

Change-Id: I8f9b5e3c6dba6ea7e3d46fdf11421e2db160bd35
(cherry picked from commit f8fd94e978a4c823800cc7d15b1afa5584dc3481)

commit_message:
Ensure mtu is set correctly on ctlplane

We were not passing the MTU when we create the ctlplane network so if
the local_mtu is less than 1500, 1500 is used by the ctlplane network in
neutron.

Change-Id: Ic7a4c5a62ff49b2f8964dd58bf5c97d9781c4ce1
Related-Bug: #1754036
(cherry picked from commit 1bc7a07decc6e4ace5115711707a69d80b969b5f)

commit_message:
Refactor some common code between overcloud_upgrade and update

Adds a new run_update_ansible_action function in utils to be used by
the upgrade and update to avoid repetition. The package_update action is
passed into the utils function to avoid circular dependency.

Change-Id: Idbe0a98fa8f2e8dfe220796c02593a805942b0da
(cherry picked from commit c6fed1f62da165ed14eff1b60a64ac5677404615)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient refs/changes/81/553281/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: oooutils.run_update_ansible_action(self.log, clients, nodes, inventory, playbook, constants.UPDATE_QUEUE, constants.MINOR_UPDATE_PLAYBOOKS, package_update)
deleted_lines: update_playbooks = [playbook] if playbook == "all": update_playbooks = constants.MINOR_UPDATE_PLAYBOOKS for book in update_playbooks: self.log.debug("Running minor update ansible playbook %s " % book) package_update.update_ansible( clients, nodes=nodes, inventory_file=inventory, playbook=book, ansible_queue_name=constants.UPDATE_QUEUE)

subject: Take mixed upgrade into account for boostrap_subnode_minimal.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-02-14 11:33:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ci/commit/6adf37727c7644c73fde7b09601fcba1f7a572f9', 'message': "WIP: Take mixed upgrade into account for boostrap_subnode_minimal.

In mixed upgrade, we have to check the UPGRADE_RELEASE to know the
version of the overcloud.

I add the newton version in there as it's needed for Fast Forward
Upgrade testing.

WIP: currently I've got timeout in the deployment of mixed version.
The overcloud is not deployed.  As it's a timeout we don't have full

Take mixed upgrade into account for boostrap_subnode_minimal.

In mixed upgrade, we have to check the UPGRADE_RELEASE to know the
version of the overcloud.

commit_message:
Extending delete_cell --force to delete instance_mappings

Currently the nova-manage delete_cell command with the --force option
allows us to destroy hosts_mappings of the cell which does not have any
instances or instance_mappings. This patch extends this command with the
--force option for destroying instance_mappings in addition to the
host_mappings of the cell which is to be deleted. Note that the instance
mappings and host mappings are only removed if there are no living
instances in the cell. So a --force delete here will not work if there
are non-deleted instances.

Change-Id: Ibefa0465224bec9a22431c7d3b5c8f5d91fc7732
Closes-Bug: #1745375
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/73/540073/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: help=_('Delete hosts and instance_mappings that belong ' 'to the cell as well.')) * It has instance mappings and force is False. If force is True and the cell has host, hosts and instance_mappings are deleted as well (as long as there are no living instances). * The cell has hosts and force is True then the cell, hosts and instance_mappings are deleted successfully; if there are no living instances. else: if not force: # There are no instances in the cell but the records remain # in the 'instance_mappings' table. print(_("There are instance mappings to cell with uuid %s," " but all instances have been deleted " "in the cell.") % cell_uuid) print(_("So execute 'nova-manage db archive_deleted_rows'" "to delete the instance mappings.")) return 4 # Delete instance_mappings of the deleted instances for instance_mapping in instance_mappings: instance_mapping.destroy()
deleted_lines: help=_('Delete hosts that belong to the cell as well.')) * It has instance mappings. If force is True and the cell has host, hosts are deleted as well. * The cell has hosts and force is True and the cell and the hosts are deleted successfully. # There are no instances in the cell but the records remains # in the 'instance_mappings' table. print(_("There are instance mappings to cell with uuid %s, " "but all instances have been deleted " "in the cell.") % cell_uuid) print(_("So execute 'nova-manage db archive_deleted_rows' to " "delete the instance mappings.")) return 4

commit_message:
Add spec for using os-client-config for service clients

It pains me to see nova expending as much effort as it does to talk to
other services. It shouldn't be that hard - and it doesn't have to be.
If we can give our end users functions like "get_legacy_client('image')"
and have them Just Work, it seems mean to withold that sort of love from
our own developers.

Spec for blueprint use-os-client-config

Change-Id: I10b9e4c91aef790fc6e4a009a9cb9657ecf5f6bb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/60/457760/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =========================================== Use os-client-config to get service clients =========================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/use-os-client-config Nova currently has a bunch of different and divergent code that attempts to create clients to talk to other services. Turns out this is hard, but also that we've already implemented it over in `os-client-config`_. Instead of having logic directly in nova where it's special and can't be re-used, just use os-client-config. .. _os-client-config: http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/os-client-config Problem description =================== Consistently configuring access to other services is complex. Up until recently it has been totally ad-hoc inside of Nova, but more recently work has been undertaken to consume service defaults out of the service catalog instead of hardcoded into nova's config. That's awesome, but we can still trim it down and get it even more consistent. Use Cases --------- For the deployer, it should get us closer to having the way a deployer indicates that how one service talks to other services to have some similarty to how End Users consume the services. On the Developer side of the fence, we can stop maintaining logic about how to properly connect to other services in multiple places and instead consume the already existing logic that knows how to to do it for all the services. Also, since things like service_type changes affect End Users and Deployers if we're using the service_catalog, sharing the logic allows us to share backwards compat workarounds. Proposed change =============== There are a few ways in which Nova creates service clients that differ from End Users. Notably, there is user of Service Accounts and also of pulling Tokens from the Request Context. These are not config vectors that `os-client-config` currently deals with, so some service oriented helper functions need to be added. A strawman proposal can be found in `https://review.openstack.org/#/c/439120/`_. Next, the call sites in Nova need to be changed to use them. An initial sketch of that can be found in `https://review.openstack.org/#/c/438512/`_, although a real implementation should likely convert one callsite at a time. Updating the mocks in the test suite is the bulk of the effort, from the dry-run stab at it. ``os-client-config`` has already landed support for skipping loading ``clouds.yaml`` files, so there does not need to be concern about introducing a yaml config format in addition to the exisiting config. Here is where you cover the change you propose to make in detail. How do you propose to solve this problem? Once Nova has been translated, we should have a clear pattern as well as direct library support that can be re-used across the other projects. It also makes it fairly easy to move to just using REST calls for a service, should that be desired. Alternatives ------------ We can continue to have a ton of wonky client creation code, and spend time caring for it and feeding it. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- ``os-client-config`` is already a dependency of ``python-openstackclient``, so the addition of the library to Nova's requirements should be fairly uneventful. Developer impact ---------------- Nova will start depending on ``os-client-config``, which means that sometimes a Nova bug might need to be fixed there, rather than in Nova. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: mordred Work Items ---------- * Finalize os-client-config service API and cut a release * Migrate vendordata-dynamic * Migrate keystone direct REST calls * Migrate placement direct REST calls * Migrate glanceclient * Migrate cinderclient * Migrate neutronclient * Migrate ironicclient * Finish migrating things to ServiceTokenAuthWrapper Dependencies ============ * Related to `<https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/use-service-catalog-for-endpoints>`_ * New dependency on ``os-client-config``. Testing ======= All of the client creation specifics can be handled by functional tests in the ``os-client-config`` tree. Since this spec is about replacing a set of code with another, the existing tests should show that it doesn't regress. Documentation Impact ==================== None .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Pike - Introduced

commit_message:
Align Ocata Apache conf with other releases

This runs the Apache conf for Ocata under horizon:horizon as we
already do for other releases.

Change-Id: I07775bd13c117b8a56295f348a9383c8ecb1ed76
Partial-bug: #1755027

deleted_lines: WSGIDaemonProcess horizon user=www-data group=www-data processes=3 threads=10

commit_message:
Queens update

This changeset contains updates for the OpenStack Queens release.

Notable changes include:
- Authentication URL for admin changed from port 35357 to port 5000.

Change-Id: Ic5664744f7d8194e45d6fe77ae7eaeb5dd7465df

commit_message:
FFU: Change order of shutdown in README.rst

We first run checks, than we shutdown services and than we disable
clustered services.

Change-Id: I14895dfbb8a38fb50ddd5ea484bf463045322248
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/32/548632/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - Step=0: Check running services - Step=1: Stop the service - Step=2: Stop the cluster
deleted_lines: - Step=1: Stop the cluster - Step=2: Stop the service

commit_message:
Enable xenial/queens amulet testing

Update amulet tests to enable xenial/queens testing; refactor to
use new amulet helpers for v2/v3 defaults switch@queens or later.

Change-Id: I09085384db6b47e7bd80a6024c170115fc936680

commit_message:
Fix up amulet for queens

* Fix up amulet tests to use keystone v3 clients.
* Add xenial/queens to gate

Change-Id: I6e870571cec65fe4cd55384c6c84761b71e92d77
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-heat refs/changes/89/549189/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: OPENSTACK_RELEASES_PAIRS = [ 'trusty_icehouse', 'trusty_kilo', 'trusty_liberty', 'trusty_mitaka', 'xenial_mitaka', 'xenial_newton', 'yakkety_newton', 'xenial_ocata', 'zesty_ocata', 'xenial_pike', 'artful_pike', 'xenial_queens', 'bionic_queens'] public_port, expected, openstack_release=None): """Validate endpoint data. Pick the correct validator based on OpenStack release. Expected data should be in the v2 format: { 'id': id, 'region': region, 'adminurl': adminurl, 'internalurl': internalurl, 'publicurl': publicurl, 'service_id': service_id} """ validation_function = self.validate_v2_endpoint_data xenial_queens = OPENSTACK_RELEASES_PAIRS.index('xenial_queens') if openstack_release and openstack_release >= xenial_queens: validation_function = self.validate_v3_endpoint_data expected = { 'id': expected['id'], 'region': expected['region'], 'region_id': 'RegionOne', 'url': self.valid_url, 'interface': self.not_null, 'service_id': expected['service_id']} return validation_function(endpoints, admin_port, internal_port, public_port, expected) def validate_v2_endpoint_data(self, endpoints, admin_port, internal_port, public_port, expected): def convert_svc_catalog_endpoint_data_to_v3(self, ep_data): """Convert v2 endpoint data into v3. { 'service_name1': [ { 'adminURL': adminURL, 'id': id, 'region': region. 'publicURL': publicURL, 'internalURL': internalURL }], 'service_name2': [ { 'adminURL': adminURL, 'id': id, 'region': region. 'publicURL': publicURL, 'internalURL': internalURL }], } """ self.log.warn("Endpoint ID and Region ID validation is limited to not " "null checks after v2 to v3 conversion") for svc in ep_data.keys(): assert len(ep_data[svc]) == 1, "Unknown data format" svc_ep_data = ep_data[svc][0] ep_data[svc] = [ { 'url': svc_ep_data['adminURL'], 'interface': 'admin', 'region': svc_ep_data['region'], 'region_id': self.not_null, 'id': self.not_null}, { 'url': svc_ep_data['publicURL'], 'interface': 'public', 'region': svc_ep_data['region'], 'region_id': self.not_null, 'id': self.not_null}, { 'url': svc_ep_data['internalURL'], 'interface': 'internal', 'region': svc_ep_data['region'], 'region_id': self.not_null, 'id': self.not_null}] return ep_data def validate_svc_catalog_endpoint_data(self, expected, actual, openstack_release=None): """Validate service catalog endpoint data. Pick the correct validator for the OpenStack version. Expected data should be in the v2 format: { 'service_name1': [ { 'adminURL': adminURL, 'id': id, 'region': region. 'publicURL': publicURL, 'internalURL': internalURL }], 'service_name2': [ { 'adminURL': adminURL, 'id': id, 'region': region. 'publicURL': publicURL, 'internalURL': internalURL }], } """ validation_function = self.validate_v2_svc_catalog_endpoint_data xenial_queens = OPENSTACK_RELEASES_PAIRS.index('xenial_queens') if openstack_release and openstack_release >= xenial_queens: validation_function = self.validate_v3_svc_catalog_endpoint_data expected = self.convert_svc_catalog_endpoint_data_to_v3(expected) return validation_function(expected, actual) def validate_v2_svc_catalog_endpoint_data(self, expected, actual): if not api_version: api_version = 2 sess, auth = self.get_keystone_session( keystone_ip=keystone_ip, username=username, password=password, api_version=api_version, admin_port=admin_port, user_domain_name=user_domain_name, domain_name=domain_name, project_domain_name=project_domain_name, project_name=project_name ) if api_version == 2: client = keystone_client.Client(session=sess) else: client = keystone_client_v3.Client(session=sess) # This populates the client.service_catalog client.auth_ref = auth.get_access(sess) return client def get_keystone_session(self, keystone_ip, username, password, api_version=False, admin_port=False, user_domain_name=None, domain_name=None, project_domain_name=None, project_name=None): """Return a keystone session object""" ep = self.get_keystone_endpoint(keystone_ip, api_version=api_version, admin_port=admin_port) if api_version == 2: else: return (sess, auth) def get_keystone_endpoint(self, keystone_ip, api_version=None, admin_port=False): """Return keystone endpoint""" port = 5000 if admin_port: port = 35357 base_ep = "http://{}:{}".format(keystone_ip.strip().decode('utf-8'), port) if api_version == 2: ep = base_ep + "/v2.0" else: ep = base_ep + "/v3" return ep def get_default_keystone_session(self, keystone_sentry, openstack_release=None): """Return a keystone session object and client object assuming standard default settings Example call in amulet tests: self.keystone_session, self.keystone = u.get_default_keystone_session( self.keystone_sentry, openstack_release=self._get_openstack_release()) The session can then be used to auth other clients: neutronclient.Client(session=session) aodh_client.Client(session=session) eyc """ self.log.debug('Authenticating keystone admin...') api_version = 2 client_class = keystone_client.Client # 11 => xenial_queens if openstack_release and openstack_release >= 11: api_version = 3 client_class = keystone_client_v3.Client keystone_ip = keystone_sentry.info['public-address'] session, auth = self.get_keystone_session( keystone_ip, api_version=api_version, username='admin', password='openstack', project_name='admin', user_domain_name='admin_domain', project_domain_name='admin_domain') client = client_class(session=session) # This populates the client.service_catalog client.auth_ref = auth.get_access(session) return session, client
deleted_lines: public_port, expected): def validate_svc_catalog_endpoint_data(self, expected, actual): port = 5000 if admin_port: port = 35357 base_ep = "http://{}:{}".format(keystone_ip.strip().decode('utf-8'), port) if not api_version or api_version == 2: ep = base_ep + "/v2.0" client = keystone_client.Client(session=sess) # This populates the client.service_catalog client.auth_ref = auth.get_access(sess) return client else: ep = base_ep + "/v3" client = keystone_client_v3.Client(session=sess) # This populates the client.service_catalog client.auth_ref = auth.get_access(sess) return client

commit_message:
Enable xenial/queens amulet tests

Updated amulet tests for xenial/queens.
Enable xenial/queens amulet test as part of extended tests.

Change-Id: I8990eadf781bd0d555267ce2cacb8ab53f78fa5b

commit_message:
Add spec for add new attributes for access rules

This new feature will give a user the ability to add new options
for each access.

Change-Id: I1416ae5a258316c599bcc2a06e828672bf164a6e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila-specs refs/changes/56/544156/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ==================================== Add new attributes for access rules ==================================== Currently allow/deny access rule attribute only supports access-level. A valid format is ro or rw. This is not enough when users want to add extra attributes, such as: all_squash. The most affected areas are API (access rules) and the drivers (access rules). Problem description =================== The user expect is that she can access her files of the shares on the server just as she would on a normal file system. This requires that the same uids and gids are used on the different clients and the server machine. This is not always true, nor is it always desirable. We have to set all_squash or other attribute to map all uids and gids to the anonymous user. For the moment Manila API of share access allow/deny does not allow to specify extra attributes of access like "all_squash" or "no_all_squash". Use Cases ========= 1. The user expect is that he want to create a public share for storing the public files, and he want this share can be accessed (read and write) by all uids and gids on the different clients. 2. The user want to access the share as group "myself" that already exist in the server when we want to allow a new access rule to a share. In order to access the file that the "myself" created. 3. The user want to set which access have higher priority to write or read the data of share, which access have lower priority to write or read the data of share. Proposed change =============== The following are the changes to be made: * A new parameter 'extra_specs' will be added to access-allow API collection. * Added new capabilities named "access_extra_specs_support" or anything else in share type. If the new capabilities isn't exist in the share type of the share, we can not allow access with '--extra_specs' parameter. * The Manila client will add a new command argument '--extra_specs' to 'access-allow' to add extra attributes in each access rule. * For compatibility with previous versions set "no_all_squash", "no_root_squash" as default value. Alternatives ------------ 1. Seting new attributes (such as: all_squash, priority) in share type, we will create a share with this share type, then we will know what the new attributes are from share type when we add a new access rule. But the problem is the all access rules of the same share will have the same attribute values. 2. Added new attributes rules (slip with '#') in access_to parameter when we add the new access to share. We will parse the value of access_to in driver. such as: "manila access-allow test_share_id user#priority=1#all_squash=1". Data model impact ----------------- The ``manila.db.sqlalchemy.models.ShareInstanceAccessMapping`` model will have a new field called ``extra_specs``. REST API impact --------------- The new parameter will be added in access API. While we will bump the micro-version to expose the 'extra_specs' parameter: **Adding an access rule** POST /v2/{tenant-id}/shares/{share-id}/action BODY:: { 'allow_access': { "access_level": "rw", "access_type": "ip", "access_to": "0.0.0.0/0" "extra_specs": "all_squash: true" } } **Listing access rules** POST /v2/{tenant-id}/shares/{share-id}/action BODY:: { 'access_list': null } Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Driver impact ------------- Drivers will report access_extra_specs_support=True when drivers support both add access rule with extra_specs. Also the following functions might need to be changed: * _update_share_stats * update_access Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: | zhongjun Work Items ---------- Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Documentation Impact ==================== The following OpenStack documentation will be updated to reflect this change: * OpenStack User Guide * OpenStack API Reference * Manila Developer Reference References ==========

commit_message:
Add extra-specs to the flavor show and detail API calls

Currently the response of ``GET /flavors/details`` and
``GET /flavors/{flavor_id}`` does not include ``extra_spces`` field,
The users have to call ``GET /flavors/{flavor_id}/extra_specs`` again
to get the extra_specs field.

UIs and SDKs like ``shade`` could time out before all the flavors and
extra-specs are retrieved.

This spec proposed to add a new microversion to the following APIs to
return also ``extra-specs`` of the flavor.

* GET /flavors/details
* GET /flavors/{flavor_id}

APIImpact

Implements: blueprint add-extra-specs-to-flavor-list

Change-Id: I0a80ce5f8327bf62766e9d47442c013c0f253737
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/58/544158/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ======================================================= Add extra-specs to the flavor show and detail API calls ======================================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/add-extra-specs-to-flavor-list Add a new microversion to the following APIs to return also ``extra-specs`` of the flavor. * GET /flavors/details * GET /flavors/{flavor_id} Problem description =================== Currently the response of ``GET /flavors/details`` and ``GET /flavors/{flavor_id}`` does not include ``extra_spces`` field, The users have to call ``GET /flavors/{flavor_id}/extra_specs`` again to get the extra_specs field. UI and SDKs like ``shade`` could time out before all the flavors and extra-specs are retrieved. Use Cases --------- Operators want to list all in-progress migrations in the cloud [1]_. Proposed change =============== Modify the following existing 2 APIs for live-migration to list and show other migration types ('evacuation', 'resize', 'migration'). * GET /servers/{server_id}/migrations * GET /servers/{server_id}/migrations/{migration_id} The former API returns in-progress migrations. The latter API returns 404 error if the specified migration is not in progress. The behavior is retained as it is. Migration status transitions are as follows: * Migration/resize - 'pre-migrating' --> 'migrating' --> 'post-migrating' --> 'finished' * Confirm resize - 'finished' --> 'confirming' --> 'confirmed' * Revert resize - 'finished' --> 'reverting' --> 'reverted' * Evacuation - 'accepted' --> 'pre-migrating' --> 'done' * Live migration - (Skip the definition) In-progress migration states are defined as follows: * migration/resize - 'pre-migrating', 'migrating', 'post-migrating' * confirm resize - 'confirming' * revert resize - 'reverting' * evacuation - 'accepted', 'pre-migrating' * live-migration - 'queued', 'preparing', 'running', 'post-migrating' - Existing definition. They remains as it is. These in-progress migrations are listed/shown, but the migration status will not be returned in the response. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- Following changes will be introduced in a new API microversion. * GET /servers/{server_id}/migrations It lists in-progress migrations. The migration type can be specified as a 'type' query parameter to filter out results. The 'type' query parameter is optional. If 'type' parameter is not specified, all migration types are listed. The valid 'type' parameters are 'live-migration', 'migration', 'resize' and 'evacuation'. If 'type' parameter is wrong, nova-api returns 400 error. So add badRequest(400) to error response codes. The 'type' parameter is added in the response. The migration status is not included in the response. JSON response body example:: { "migrations": [ { "dest_host": "10.0.2.15", "memory_processed_bytes": null, "type": "migration", "updated_at": "2017-01-31T08:03:25.000000", "created_at": "2017-01-31T08:03:21.000000", "memory_remaining_bytes": null, "dest_compute": "devstack-master2", "id": 11, "source_node": "devstack-master1", "server_uuid": "a333ee8a-367f-4841-bdc9-c8d92a6adfe4", "memory_total_bytes": null, "dest_node": "devstack-master2", "disk_total_bytes": null, "disk_processed_bytes": null, "disk_remaining_bytes": null, "source_compute": "devstack-master1" } ] } * GET /servers/{server_id}/migrations/{migration_id} The response codes are not modified. Show a migration which has any migration type. The 'type' parameter is added in the response. The migration status is not included in the response. JSON response body example:: { "migration": { "dest_host": "10.0.2.15", "memory_processed_bytes": null, "type": "migration", "updated_at": "2017-01-31T08:03:25.000000", "created_at": "2017-01-31T08:03:21.000000", "memory_remaining_bytes": null, "dest_compute": "devstack-master2", "id": 11, "source_node": "devstack-master1", "server_uuid": "a333ee8a-367f-4841-bdc9-c8d92a6adfe4", "memory_total_bytes": null, "dest_node": "devstack-master2", "disk_total_bytes": null, "disk_processed_bytes": null, "disk_remaining_bytes": null, "source_compute": "devstack-master1" } } If a migration is not in-progress state, it returns 404 error. * POST /servers/{server_id}/migrations/{migration_id}/action It is a "Force Migration Complete Action" API. The migration is not a 'live-migration', it returns 400 error instead of 404 error. * DELETE /servers/{server_id}/migrations/{migration_id} If the migration is not a 'live-migration', it returns 400 error. It is a current behavior. (It is not changed.) Security impact --------------- Only Administrator can operate suggested functions by default. So there is no security impact. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- The novaclient and openstackclient are modified to specify a migration type. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: natsume-takashi Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- * Add the 'type' query parameter to list server migrations ('evacuation', 'resize', 'migration') API * Modify show a server migration ('evacuation', 'resize', or 'migration') API * Add the optional 'type' parameter in novaclient/openstackclient * API docs including note of the possible types Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Add the following tests. * functional tests * tempest test Documentation Impact ==================== * API Reference * CLI Reference References ========== .. [1] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/abort-cold-migration History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Pike - Approved * - Queens - Reproposed

commit_message:
[Docs] Move the upgrade reference into reference

Now that the upgrade should have moved to the operations guide,
the upgrade reference should head in th reference guide.

In order to accomodate the new data into reference, the reference
landing page now links to both inventory and upgrades.

Change-Id: Ieb3eb0627854b80a7fed532702b77a7ec9a36e64

commit_message:
Nova: Fix sudoers location in nova-etc configmap

The nova_sudoers entry in the nova configmap-etc was consuming
the neutron_sudoers entry in the values.yaml. This corrects it to
point at nova_sudoers instead

Change-Id: I621c817c579cc1c31fa51b1a0f49a43a652784a2

commit_message:
Add barbican-tempest experimental job

The barbican-tempest-plugin has tests for
volume encryption, which uses cinder. This
patch adds the barbican-tempest-plugin tests
to the cinder experimental zuulv3 jobs, so
that it can be run against patches that
might affect volume encryption functionality.

Change-Id: If30a4c91134153de02508bae8391eb7014eb1b8b

added_lines: By default, OpenStack-Ansible automatically applies the ansible-hardening roleThe role is applicable to physical hosts within an OpenStack-Ansible deployment that are operating as any type of node, infrastructure or compute. By default, the role is enabled. You can disable it by changing the value of the ``apply_security_hardening`` variable in the ``user_variables.yml`` file to ``false``: .. code-block:: yaml apply_security_hardening: false You can apply security hardening configurations to an existing environment or audit an environment by using a playbook supplied with OpenStack-Ansible: .. code-block:: bash # Apply security hardening configurations openstack-ansible security-hardening.yml # Perform a quick audit by using Ansible's check mode openstack-ansible --check security-hardening.yml
deleted_lines: By default, OpenStack-Ansible automatically applies the security hardening role

commit_message:
[Docs] Introduce next steps

To be more like a walkthrough, the next step after the
verification of the environment would be to contribute and
operate OpenStack-Ansible.

This could also bring more visibility to contributions.

Change-Id: I991ad7963bcd777e279738bb9d4ca03992f46280

commit_message:
[Docs] Link to the AIO

Anyone wanting to quickly deploy an openstack-ansible cloud has no
way to know we have an AIO toolkit that could help.

This should fix it.

Change-Id: I7cabfac0bfb01b77e2a250e5879671c95cbb46c6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/48/544248/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. note:: If you want to do a quick proof of concept of OpenStack, read the `All-In-One quickstart Guide <https://docs.openstack.org/openstack-ansible/latest/contributor/quickstart-aio.html>`_ instead of this document. This document is a walkthrough of a deploy using OpenStack-Ansible, with all its configurability. All the successive chapters to deploy are listed in the left column.

commit_message:
Hardware interface for BIOS configuration

The proposal presents the work required to create
a hardware interface for BIOS configuration.

Co-Authored-By: Yolanda Robla <yroblamo@redhat.com>
Partial-Bug: #1712032
Change-Id: I8cfdeb78454e02a3d2d0821ddb4f965003d3feaa
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/81/496481/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =========================================== New driver interface for BIOS configuration =========================================== https://bugs.launchpad.net/ironic/+bug/1712032 The proposal is intended to create a new driver interface for BIOS automated configuration and a method to make BIOS configuration available as part of manual cleaning. Problem description =================== * Currently there is no support in Ironic to do BIOS configuration. * There are several use cases that need to configure BIOS options to enable certain functionality or gain performance optimization on openstack compute nodes. For example, in order to use SRIOV or DPDK technologies, the 'Virtualization Technology' BIOS option shall be enabled; to achieve deterministic low packet latency in real time scenario, BIOS options related to Power Management, CPU sleep states etc shall be disabled. Proposed change =============== * After a node is enrolled and the basic hardware information is available, the operator can define a BIOS configuration. * The operator can convey the BIOS configuration information to the Ironic driver through REST APIs or CLI as JSON data. The BIOS configuration information will contain the BIOS properties that are expected to be changed. * New driver interface called ``BIOSInterface`` will be provided for BIOS configuration for drivers. Refer to Driver API impact section for more details. * A new method ``update_bios_info`` will be available in the base class of ``BIOSInterface``. This method may be used by the driver implementation of ``create_configuration``, ``get_configuration`` and ``get_properties`` to update BIOS information in the Node database. * New methods ``create_configuration``, ``get_configuration`` and ``get_properties`` in ``BIOSInterface`` will be available as part of manual cleaning. The operator can choose to call them as part of manual cleaning steps. The corresponding manual cleaning steps will be ``node.bios.create_configuration``, ``node.bios.get_configuration`` and ``node.bios.get_properties``. * New REST APIs will be created for BIOS configuration. For more details, refer to the REST API impact section. * Three new options will be available in Ironic CLI for doing the BIOS configuration. To set a new BIOS configuration:: $ ironic node-set-bios-configuration <node-uuid> --from-file bios_conf.json To get the current and target BIOS configuration:: $ ironic node-get-bios-configuration <node-uuid> To get the BIOS properties available for configuration and their possible values:: $ ironic node-get-bios-properties <node-uuid> Alternatives ------------ * Operator can change the BIOS configuration manually whenever required. But this has to be done for each node which is time-consuming and error-prone. Data model impact ----------------- The following fields in the Node object will be added: * ``node.target_bios_config`` will store the pending BIOS configuration to be applied during manual cleaning. * ``node.bios_config`` will store the last applied BIOS configuration. This will also contain the timestamp of when this configuration was applied. * ``node.bios_properties`` will store the BIOS properties available for configuration. State Machine Impact -------------------- None REST API impact --------------- Three new REST APIs will be introduced as part of this change. - To create the BIOS configuration for a node, run:: PUT /nodes/<uuid>/bios/configuration This operation will write the configuration to the ``node.target_bios_config`` and will be applied during the manual cleaning. The JSON data of the BIOS configuration as mentioned above needs to be passed as data to this request. Updating the BIOS configuration will be prevented if BIOS configuration is in progress from the driver. This will also validate the target BIOS configuration by calling ``validate_configuration`` method on the ``BIOSInterface``. .. note:: This API doesn't actually do the BIOS configuration. It just stores the input for BIOS configuration in the Ironic database. The BIOS configuration will be done as part of manual cleaning. If the operation is success, then the API will return HTTP 202 (Accepted). If the operation failed, either becasue the driver doesn't support BIOS configuration or validation of input failed, then the API will return HTTP 400 (Bad Request). - To get the BIOS configuration:: Get /nodes/<uuid>/bios/configuration This operation will return the current and target BIOS configuration. Example 1: After putting a BIOS configuration using ``PUT``:: { 'current': None 'target': { 'ProcVirtualization': 'Enabled', 'SriovGlobalEnable': 'Enabled', ... } } Example 2: After the BIOS configuration is applied as part of manual cleaning:: { 'current': { 'ProcVirtualization': 'Enabled', 'SriovGlobalEnable': 'Enabled', ... } 'target': None } .. note:: Examples above only list some of BIOS options for reference, the real output of current and target content depend on hardware and user input. If driver doesn't support BIOS configuration, then the API will return HTTP 400 (Bad Request). Otherwise the API will return HTTP 200 (OK). - To get the BIOS properties available for configuration and possible values:: GET /drivers/<driver>/bios/properties The operation will return the properties and a textual description of the possible values for each property:: { 'ProcVirtualization': 'Supported values are Enabled, Disabled.', 'SriovGlobalEnable': 'Supported values are Enabled, Disabled.', ... } If driver doesn't support BIOS configuration, then the API will return HTTP 400 (Bad Request). Otherwise the API will return HTTP 200 (OK). Client (CLI) impact ------------------- Refer to REST API impact for details. RPC API impact -------------- Two new RPC APIs will be created. The corresponding methods will defined in the conductor for handling these functionalities. - ``set_target_bios_config`` - This method will be called in ``PUT /nodes/<uuid>/bios/configuration``. - ``get_current_bios_config`` - This method will be called in ``GET /drivers/<driver>/bios/properties``. - ``get_bios_properties`` - This method will be called in ``GET /drivers/<driver>/bios/properties``. Driver API impact ----------------- A new ``BIOSInterface`` will be available for the drivers to allow them to implement BIOS configuration. There will be two methods in the interface: - ``create_configuration()`` - The driver implementation of this method has to read the request BIOS configuration from ``node.target_bios_config`` and apply BIOS configuration on the bare metal. The driver must ensure ``ironic.common.bios.update_bios_info()`` be called at the end of the process updating the ``bios_config``. The implementation detail is up to the driver. - ``get_configuration()`` - The driver implementation of this method has to retrieve the current BIOS configuration on the bare metal and ensure ``ironic.common.bios.update_bios_info()`` be called at the end of the process updating the ``bios_config``. - ``get_properties()`` - The driver implementation of this method has to retrieve the BIOS properties available for configuration and possible values on the bare metal. The driver must ensure ``ironic.common.bios.update_bios_info()`` be called at the end of the process updating the ``bios_properties``. Nova driver impact ------------------ None Ramdisk impact -------------- None Security impact --------------- Other end user impact --------------------- None Scalability impact ------------------ None Performance Impact ------------------ BIOS configuration may extend the time required for manual cleaning on the nodes. Other deployer impact --------------------- Operator can use ``node.bios.create_configuration``, ``node.bios.get_configuration`` and ``node.bios.get_properties`` as manual cleaning tasks for doing BIOS management. Developer impact ---------------- Discuss things that will affect other developers working on OpenStack, such as: * If the blueprint proposes a change to the driver API, discussion of how other drivers would implement the feature is required. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: zshi Work Items ---------- + Create bios fields in Node object. + Create REST API endpoints for BIOS configuration. + Create RPC APIs and corresponding methods in ironic conductor. + Create ``BIOSInterface`` and create a fake implementation of ``BIOSInterface``. + Implement ``update_bios_info`` in ``BIOSInterface``. + Implement Ironic CLI changes. + Write unit tests. Dependencies ============ * Manual cleaning - https://github.com/openstack/ironic-specs/blob/master/specs/approved/manual-cleaning.rst Testing ======= * Unit tests will be added for the code. A fake implementation of the ``BIOSInterface`` will be provided for testing purpose and this can be run as part of manual cleaning. * Each driver is responsible for providing the third party CI for testing the BIOS configuration. Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== None Documentation Impact ==================== Dodumentation will be provided on how to configure a node for BIOS. References ==========

commit_message:
Fail in test_titles of ironic-specs

When run tox to test, the error below appears:
...
dict(expect.items() + allowed.items())]

TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for +:
'dict_items' and 'dict_items'
...

Change-Id: I54154927e08d04248301d4d29de1d88d13890c01
Closes-Bug: #1755169

commit_message:
Add HW_NIC_SRIOV_TRUSTED trait

Adds a new trait to indicate whether all VFs on a PF or a single VF on a
PF is "trusted" and therefore able to operate in promiscuous mode.

Change-Id: If9d4af6ae7158ff8bcab6cdcd979145af307ce84

commit_message:
Add LDAP-backed domain gate

This patch set adds a nv-gating with an OpenLDAP server with some sample
data loaded for development or testing use using a bootstrap job.
This patch set also adds confirming authentication works using  domain-
specific configuration for keystone.

Consolidated change from: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/552976/
Co-Authored-By: Gage Hugo <gagehugo@gmail.com>

Change-Id: I1aeccffc018d0fcefc8e2b15a4ac6b83cb2be8b6
Signed-off-by: Tin Lam <tin@irrational.io>

commit_message:
Fix CI (QoS and running func tests against OVS 2.9 fixes)

This is a combination of 2 commits as we need both to unblock the gate
right now. One will fix the CI due to QoS changes in neutron and the
other will make functional tests running against OVS 2.9 since master is
currently breaking those. Both depend on each other so this is the
reason behind of the squash.

Fix CI broke because of QoS interface and neutron DB interface changes

all_rules = qos_rule.get_rules(context, policy_id)
TypeError: get_rules() takes exactly 3 arguments (2 given)

qos_rule.get_rules() add a arguments (obj_cls) in this commit:
https://github.com/openstack/neutron/commit/6f83466307fb21aee5bb596974644d457ae1fa60#diff-94eb611a8a3b29dbf8cd2aa2466a53b9R34

This code results in a DB commit for each operation (get_object/delete_object/update_object):
https://github.com/openstack/neutron/commit/6f83466307fb21aee5bb596974644d457ae1fa60#diff-7ed10a69652bc41264bbb5ae42eb8867R526
This led to the port's revision_number increase.

Run tempest release job and functional tests against OVS 2.9

This patch makes both the functional tests and tempest release
job to run against OVS 2.9 which is the latest release at the
time that stable/queens is going to be released.

This is also fixing the functional tests that currently run
against OVS master branch and currently breaks those.

Depends-On: I3ea043758f813f33b4e42eae29b12fadd2e66f7c
Change-Id: I4f3df7b98f7cfcea94367f83f055b3db0450e761
Closes-bug: #1750599
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Auto-configure WSGI worker processes

Automatically configure WSGI worker processes inline with other
charms using the worker-multiplier configuration option and the
WSGI worker configuration context from charm-helpers.

Change-Id: Ib8af4a5a54fcff13a05ba4f4094bf123d5282c4a

commit_message:
DHCP agent: Handle endpoint with no ipNetworks

If the endpoint has no ipNetworks, treat as deletion.  This happens when
a resync from the mechanism driver overlaps with a port/VM being
deleted.

Before handling this case, we got a traceback like this:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/bin/calico-dhcp-agent", line 10, in <module>
    sys.exit(main())
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/networking_calico/agent/dhcp_agent.py", line 619, in main
    agent.run()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/osprofiler/profiler.py", line 153, in wrapper
    return f(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/networking_calico/agent/dhcp_agent.py", line 585, in run
    self.etcd.start()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/networking_calico/agent/dhcp_agent.py", line 167, in start
    super(CalicoEtcdWatcher, self).start()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/networking_calico/etcdutils.py", line 323, in start
    self.dispatcher.handle_event(response)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/networking_calico/etcdutils.py", line 73, in handle_event
    self._handle(key_parts, response, self.handler_root, {})
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/networking_calico/etcdutils.py", line 91, in _handle
    handler_node[action](response, **captures)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/networking_calico/agent/dhcp_agent.py", line 278, in on_endpoint_set
    port['network_id'] = self._ensure_net_and_subnets(port)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/networking_calico/agent/dhcp_agent.py", line 325, in _ensure_net_and_subnets
    assert new_subnets
AssertionError

Change-Id: Ic8aa642c8b8c23066bc92e14743b2d0c83ce3459

subject: playbooks: containers-lxc-host: Set correct disk size limit for containers
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-03-14 08:29:56.000000000', 'files': ['playbooks/containers-lxc-host.yml', 'tests/roles/bootstrap-host/templates/user_variables.aio.yml.j2'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/743cb4397169d2c772e9b4a9dbffbbebe9f31beb', 'message': 'playbooks: containers-lxc-host: Set correct disk size limit for containers

We need to set the lxc_host_machine_volume_size variable based on the
size of the disk which holds the container images. This avoids spurious
problems in the gates when we run out of disk space inside the
containers.

Change-Id: I3dfea24f6eb9d179174222b907c29126168bbb4e
'}]
commit_message:
playbooks: containers-lxc-host: Set correct disk size limit for containers

We need to set the lxc_host_machine_volume_size variable based on the
size of the disk which holds the container images. This avoids spurious
problems in the gates when we run out of disk space inside the
containers.

Change-Id: I3dfea24f6eb9d179174222b907c29126168bbb4e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/36/552836/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: # Allow the container store sufficient space to build everything we need. # Size is in GB: lxc_host_machine_volume_size: 1024

commit_message:
Simplify SELinux check

The ansible_selinux variable is always populated with a 'status'
property, even if SELinux is not installed or configured. This
patch simplifies the check.

Change-Id: Ifddc385fc292ddb7d6c2758b199401c45de0f0f2
Signed-off-by: Major Hayden <major@mhtx.net>

commit_message:
Update config option for collecting sensor data

This patch updates the notification driver option for collecting sensor
data because [DEFAULT]/notification_driver is deprecated and
'messaging' driver should only be used in cases where there are existing
consumers deployed which do not support the 2.0 message format.

Change-Id: Ia6c55149e5cb12d1201742f7008047e35570b410
(cherry picked from commit 013992bf6668d81e7a5649a313f7475907a644b7)

commit_message:
devstack: add support for rescue mode

This adds config for setting rescue interface for node,
rescue network, and rescue images.

Change-Id: I332223f187783fc06e19e62a886a8a7378c62cf2
Partial-Bug: 1526449
Co-Authored-By: Mario Villaplana <mario.villaplana@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Annie Lezil <annie.lezil@gmail.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/18/524118/23 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: IRONIC_ENABLED_RESCUE_INTERFACES=${IRONIC_ENABLED_RESCUE_INTERFACES:-"agent,no-rescue"}IRONIC_DEFAULT_RESCUE_INTERFACE=${IRONIC_DEFAULT_RESCUE_INTERFACE:-}# This is the rescue interface to use for a node IRONIC_RESCUE_INTERFACE=${IRONIC_RESCUE_INTERFACE:-} if [[ -n "${IRONIC_RESCUE_INTERFACE}" ]]; then $IRONIC_CMD node set $node_id --rescue-interface $IRONIC_RESCUE_INTERFACE || \ die $LINENO "Failed to update rescue interface for node $node_id" fi

doc update: better introduction, more links

* avoid having the same intro text in two files (use an include)
* avoid giving the impression that EVPN support is a mere possibility
* update some intro and README.rst text
* link to summit presentation videos

commit_message:
SPEC: nova disk quota tracking

APIImpact

Change-Id: I36f923be51ec187f51d93e49c5f5d061b6463f42
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/47/486947/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ======================== Nova disc quota tracking ======================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/nova-disk-quota-tracking Nova has lots of resource quotas, but not for allocated storage to VMs. Problem description =================== Now, it is not possible to limit user with some specific amount of root and ephemeral disc storage allocated to VM during boot based on flavor's values. Because of absence of such quota we are forced to rely on Cinder volumes to be able to bill for storage and restrict storage in flavors. Use Cases --------- In case we care only about allocated storage in general and not on allocation means, whether it is Cinder or root disc for VM, we would need a storage quotas in nova. So, cloud admins will have more flexibility for storage tracking. Proposed change =============== It is proposed to create additional quota resource called, for example, 'local_gb' that will consist of root disc and ephemeral storage, that nova has been tracking for long time. It will require small update of API, where we show new quota resource in addition to existing ones and allow to update it with quota and quota class sets. Also, we will need to create new configuration option with default value, in the same way it is done for all other existing quotas. Alternatives ------------ The only alternative is to continue doing things as is, not tracking storage we allocate for nova VMs based on its flavor. Data model impact ----------------- No DB models changes are expected, because nova already tracks such kind of a storage, just doesn't use it for quotas. REST API impact --------------- Bump of microversion will be required, because we will extend existing 'quota-sets', 'quota-class-sets' and 'limits' APIs. Following API changes are expected to be implemented: * 1) quota show API * URL: /v2.1/os-quota-sets/<scope> * Method: GET * Proposed update to JSON response:: { "quota_set": { "ram": 51200, ... "local_gb": 1024, ... "cores": 20 } } * 2) quota update API * URL: /v2.1/os-quota-sets/<scope> * Method: PUT * Proposed update to JSON request:: { "quota_set": { "local_gb": 1024 } } * Proposed update to JSON response:: { "quota_set": { "local_gb": 1024 } } * 3) quota class show API * URL: /v2.1/os-quota-class-sets/<scope> * Method: GET * Proposed update to JSON response:: { "quota_class_set": { "ram": 51200, ... "local_gb": 1024, ... "cores": 20 } } * 4) quota class update API * URL: /v2.1/os-quota-class-sets/<scope> * Method: PUT * Proposed update to JSON request:: { "quota_class_set": { "local_gb": 1024 } } * Proposed update to JSON response:: { "quota_class_set": { "local_gb": 1024 } } * 5) View existing limits and usages API * URL: /v2.1/limits * Method: GET * Proposed update to JSON response:: { "limits": { "rate": [], "absolute": { "maxTotalRAMSize": 51200, ... "maxLocalGBSize": 1024, ... "maxTotalCores": 20 } } } Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- No changes to notification mechanism or its usage is expected, because we will reuse existing nova logic for one more resource quota. Other end user impact --------------------- - Users will not be able anymore to abuse of storage resources provided by flavors. - We will need to update python-novaclient to be able to update new quota. Performance Impact ------------------ In theory, we will have some additional logic for taking decision about whether a user is allowed to boot VM with specific flavor based on its storage or not. In practise, this logic is very cheap operation. Other deployer impact --------------------- Deployer will need to define one more configuration option called, for example, "quota_local_gb" in case default value is not suitable for his deployment. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Artem Tiumentcev ("darland-maik" at lauchpad.net) Work Items ---------- - Update quotas and limits API bumping API microversion. - Update python-novaclient to support this new server feature. - Update docs with new quota resource description. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Several kinds of tests can be added for covering this feature: - unit tests in nova - functional tests in nova - API and scenario tests in tempest Documentation Impact ==================== Small changes to docs will be required, where we will describe one new quota resource. References ========== None History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Queens - Introduced

commit_message:
Patrole (RBAC) Nova Gating

The purpose of this spec is to outline a proposal for adding RBAC
testing gates Nova by leveraging Patrole, a Tempest plugin.

Change-Id: I9e1448ca5f5d98d16de206f7939e6d7c12993618
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/45/471145/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================ Patrole - RBAC Testing Framework ================================ Patrole is an OpenStack Tempest plugin responsible for Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) testing. It leverages pre-existing Tempest API clients to test each API endpoint against an expected policy action. Even though Patrole started as a plugin only capable of validating policy.json files, it has since been enhanced to support in-code policies, an improvement to RBAC spearheaded first by Nova, quickly followed by Keystone. Currently, the future of policy enforcement within OpenStack is an area of ongoing innovation and discussion. Just as policy changes should be carefully crafted an documented, so too so they be tested. Thus, Nova stands to benefit from an RBAC testing framework by using a Patrole non-voting gate to validate Nova's policy enforcement. Problem Description =================== Introduction ------------ Patrole was developed to debug and validate custom roles introduced into policy.json files from a high-level perspective. While some services have unit tests that validate policy enforcement, these unit tests are neither robust enough nor ubiquituous across all services and APIs. And while Tempest segregates admin-level tests from non-admin-level tests, based on the `default` permissions for each API, this approach can easily be broken when the default permissions are modified. For example, if default policy actions are modified to allow admin role instead of anyone, then corresponding Tempest tests for the APIs that enforce the modified policy actions will necessarily break, because Tempest has no mechanism for dynamically changing the credentials it uses to perform an API call in its testing. Since its introduction, Patrole has evolved to be able to test in-code policy defaults. Patrole should target such projects for RBAC testing, because: 1. Policy in code is documented. It is easier to verify that RBAC tests are written correctly because each API that enforces a policy can be referenced. 2. Policy in code is `complete`. Unlike some services that do not exhaustively enumerate all their policies in their policy,json file, which makes verifying whether a policy action even exists more difficult, Nova is relatively straightforward to test. 3. Given the above items, it can be argued that policy in code is more "stable". Patrole Policy Verification --------------------------- Patrole includes a test for each API that enforces a policy -- so long as the API can be called via a Tempest client. As already mentioned, Patrole supports policy in code, by using logic similar to ``generator.py`` in `oslo.policy <https://github.com/openstack/oslo.policy/blob/master/oslo_policy/generator.py#L62>`_ Policy verification is performed by: 1. Pooling together the default `in-code` policy rules. 2. Overriding the defaults with custom policy rules located in a policy.json, if the policy file exists and the custom policy definition is explicitly defined therein. 3. Confirming that the policy action -- for example, "list_users" -- exists. (``oslopolicy-checker`` otherwise claims that role "foo" is allowed to perform policy action "bar", for example, because it defers to the ``default`` policy rule and sometimes the default can be "anyone allowed"). 4. Performing a call with all necessary data to ``oslo.policy``. 5. Comparing the output from ``oslo.policy`` to the output from the corresponding API call that enforces the policy action: A "consistent" result is treated as a pass and an "inconsistent" result is treated as a failure. "Consistency" here means, for example, a 200 from the API call and a ``True`` result from ``oslo.policy`` or a 403 from the API call and a ``False`` result from ``oslo.policy`` -- and vice versa for the "inconsistency" definition. (There are many other combinations, but they are not exhaustively enumerated here.) Negative Testing ---------------- In addition, while many tests may currently offer some semblance of RBAC testing, they usually only test the so-called "happy path", thereby neglecting negative testing, which entails validating that unauthorized users cannot perform specific API actions. In other words, negative RBAC testing -- which is arguably more important from a `security` standpoint than positive RBAC testing -- is baked into the Patrole framework. Solution ======== Summary ------- There are two possible solutions, depending on the type of coverage desired by Nova: either Nova-specific Patrole tests can be run, or all Patrole tests can be run. .. note:: Currently, Patrole only supports RBAC testing for Nova, Neutron, Keystone, Cinder and Glance. Swift is not yet covered. .. The solution is to add a Patrole non-voting gate in Nova, responsible for testing Nova-specific APIs or for testing all Big Tent APIs (minus Swift), for both of the currently supported roles across these services: admin and Member. The tests should be split into separate gates for each role to provide proper test isolation between roles, which will facilitate debugging of the gates. Note that it is nonetheless possible to execute tests for both roles within a single gate, if required, although this approach will result in much longer net gate execution time (probably an hour and change). The implementation details are relatively straightforward: Patrole's current approach to doing RBAC testing within its own gate can be adopted, with only one modification required: altering the regex passed to Tempest runner. Work Items ~~~~~~~~~~ * Implement a tox job for executing Patrole tests. * Implement a non-voting admin gate for Patrole tests in Nova infra job and run the tox job with the admin role. * Implement a non-voting Member gate Patrole tests in Nova infra job infra and run the tox job with the Member role. Current Test Coverage --------------------- Patrole currently executes more than 125 Mpva RBAC tests within its own project gate for each of the two primary OpenStack roles: admin and Member. In addition, Patrole executes more than 470 RBAC tests currently, across all Big Tent services. Note that Patrole requires the Tempest client as a prerequisite, so Patrole's test coverage can only ever be tantamount to (give or take) Tempest's test coverage. .. note:: Also, at this time, Patrole has no stable, consumable library like ``tempest.lib``, so Nova would not be able to have in-repo Patrole tests, at least not until ``patrole.lib`` is developed. .. Gate Execution Time ------------------- Each gate takes approximately 40 to 50 minutes to execute -- but that is across all "Big Tent" services for which Patrole offers testing. Patrole gates dedicated to testing just Nova APIs ought to be much faster, probably within the ballpark of 30 minutes. Testing ======= Testing would be straightforward: verify that all the tests pass in the Patrole gates added to the Nova repo. Conclusion ========== The end result is proactive RBAC testing within Nova. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Felipe Monteiro <felipe.monteiro@att.com> Other contributors: * Samantha Blanco <samantha.blanco@att.com> * Rick Bartra <rb560u@att.com> References ========== The references below include documentation for Patrole and ``oslopolicy-checker``, along with a code example from `oslo.policy`. * `Patrole <https://docs.openstack.org/developer/patrole/>`_ * `oslo.policy <https://github.com/openstack/oslo.policy/blob/master/oslo_policy/generator.py#L62>`_ * `oslopolicy-checker <https://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.policy/cli.html>`_
